item.title: Follow THESE 5 measures to increase immunity and protect newborn from diseases in winter - India TV News
item.description:
5 Essential Tips to Boost Immunity in Newborns During Winter

Publication Date: December 23, 2024
Source: India TV News

Newborns have delicate immune systems that require special care to prevent infections. Strengthening their immunity is crucial, especially during the winter months when they are more vulnerable. Here are five effective measures to enhance the immunity of newborns and protect them from seasonal diseases.

  • 1. Breastfeeding: Breast milk, including colostrum, is vital for providing antibodies and nutrition.
  • 2. Cleanliness: Regularly clean your baby's environment and items to reduce infection risks.
  • 3. Maintain the right temperature: Keep the baby warm in cold weather with appropriate clothing.
  • 4. Vaccination: Ensure timely vaccinations to protect against serious diseases.
  • 5. Nutrient-Rich Food: After 6 months, provide solid foods rich in nutrients to support development and immunity.

Taking these steps can significantly boost a newborn's immunity and contribute to their overall health and growth.

item.title: Drinking tea and coffee linked to lower risk of head and neck cancer in study - The Guardian
item.description:
Drinking Tea and Coffee Linked to Lower Risk of Head and Neck Cancer

Publication Date: November 12, 2023
Source: The Guardian

Researchers have found that consuming tea and coffee is associated with a lower risk of head and neck cancers.

  • About 12,800 new cases of head and neck cancer and 4,100 deaths occur in the UK annually.
  • The study analyzed data from 14 studies across Europe, North America, and Latin America.
  • Participants consuming over four cups of caffeinated coffee a day have a 17% lower chance of developing head and neck cancers.
  • One cup of tea a day seems to reduce overall risk by 9%, but more than one cup may increase the risk of laryngeal cancer by 38%.
  • Self-reporting by participants is a limitation of the study.
“Perhaps bioactive compounds other than caffeine contribute to the potential anti-cancer effect of coffee and tea.” – Dr. Yuan-Chin Amy Lee

This research provides significant insights into dietary factors potentially influencing cancer risks, though caution is advised in interpreting observational study results.

item.description:
10 Indian Drinks to Help Reduce Belly Fat Quickly

  • Buttermilk with spices aids digestion and reduces bloating.
“Natural options to reduce belly fat are safer, free from harmful side effects, and promote holistic health.”

The discussed drinks can be beneficial for those looking to manage their weight effectively while enjoying traditional flavors.

item.title: Constipation Awareness Month 2024: 10 Changes Everyone Can Make To Their Diet For Better Digestion - NDTV
item.description:
Constipation Awareness Month 2024: 10 Changes Everyone Can Make To Their Diet For Better Digestion

Published on: April 2, 2024 by NDTV

December is recognized as Constipation Awareness Month, focusing on educating the public about constipation, its causes, and prevention methods. Chronic constipation can lead to serious complications, and dietary changes play a key role in managing this condition.

  • Increase fibre intake with soluble and insoluble sources.
  • Stay hydrated by drinking at least eight glasses of water daily.
  • Incorporate probiotics through foods like yogurt and fermented vegetables.
  • Limit processed foods to enhance digestive efficiency.
  • Eat regular, balanced meals to support digestive health.
  • Chew food thoroughly to aid in digestion.
  • Avoid excessive caffeine and alcohol to prevent dehydration.
  • Incorporate healthy fats for better nutrient absorption.
  • Include natural laxative foods like kiwis and prunes.
  • Practice mindful eating for improved digestion.
“Implementing these dietary changes can lead to significant improvements in digestive health, reducing the incidence of constipation and enhancing overall well-being.”

It's vital to introduce these changes gradually and consult healthcare professionals for personalized advice.

item.title: Harvard University shares 7 tips to keep your memory sharp at any age - Hindustan Times
item.description:
7 Tips from Harvard University to Improve Memory at Any Age

Publication Date: December 20, 2024 | Source: Hindustan Times

As we age, keeping our memory sharp can become a challenge. Harvard University has provided seven tips to help individuals maintain and enhance their memory regardless of their age.

  • Keep Learning: Engaging in continuous education can help keep the brain active.
  • Use All Your Senses: Involve multiple senses during learning for better retention.
  • Believe in Yourself: Positive self-belief can aid memory improvement.
  • Economize Your Brain Use: Organize everyday items to avoid cluttering your memory.
  • Repeat What You Want to Know: Reinforce memory by repeating information aloud or in writing.
  • Space It Out: Use spaced repetition at intervals to enhance memory retention.
  • Make a Mnemonic: Use creative mnemonics for easier recall of information.
"Engaging the whole brain through varied learning strategies enhances memory retention."

By incorporating these tips into daily routines, individuals can enhance their cognitive ability and maintain sharper memories as they age.

item.title: Explained: Why the HPV vaccine is a must for preventing cervical cancer - News9 LIVE
item.description:
Explained: Why the HPV vaccine is a must for preventing cervical cancer

Date: New Delhi

Source: News9

The Human Papillomavirus (HPV) vaccination is crucial for preventing cervical cancer, as nearly all cervical cancer cases are linked to HPV infection. Most HPV infections resolve on their own, but about 5% can lead to persistent infections that cause cancer.

  • Nearly all sexually active individuals will encounter at least one type of HPV in their lives.
  • Approximately 70% of cervical cancer cases are caused by HPV types 16 and 18.
  • Common vaccines include Cervarix, Gardasil, and Gardasil 9.
  • The ideal vaccination age is 9-10 years, with catch-up vaccinations recommended up to age 26.
  • The vaccine does not treat existing HPV infections; regular cervical cancer screenings remain essential.
"Widespread vaccination programs have significantly reduced HPV infections, genital warts, and precancerous cervical lesions in vaccinated populations."

The HPV vaccine is a powerful tool in preventing cervical and other cancers caused by HPV. Regular screenings are still necessary, even for vaccinated individuals.

item.title: 50% of men aged 51-60 and up to 90% of those over 80 suffers from BPH: Says Dr. Rochan pant - Business News This Week
item.description:
High Prevalence of BPH in Aging Men: Insights from Dr. Rochan Pant

Publication Date: December 2024 | Source: Business News This Week

This article discusses the prevalence of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) among men, particularly noting that 50% of men aged 51-60 and up to 90% of those over 80 are affected. Dr. Rochan Pant emphasizes the importance of minimally invasive treatments like Prostate Artery Embolization (PAE).

  • 50% of men aged 51-60 are affected by BPH.
  • Up to 90% of men over 80 experience this condition.
  • PAE offers a safer alternative to traditional surgeries for BPH treatment.
  • Healthy lifestyle choices positively influence prostate health.
“Patients with prostate symptoms are older, and often have many other illnesses... My patients are delighted with how simple, pain free, and effective PAE is.” - Dr. Rochan Pant

In conclusion, for those suffering from an enlarged prostate, exploring minimally invasive treatment options can lead to better outcomes and quality of life.

item.title: The silent killer: Why stroke remains a leading cause of death and disability - The Times of India
item.description:
The silent killer: Why stroke remains a leading cause of death and disability

Publication Date: [Insert Date Here] Source: [Insert Source Here]

This article explores the significant causes and consequences of strokes, shedding light on why it remains a prominent cause of death and disability worldwide.

  • Stroke is a leading cause of mortality and long-term disability.
  • Understanding risk factors can help in prevention.
  • Early intervention and awareness are crucial for improving outcomes.
  • Statistics indicate increasing incidence rates in certain demographics.
  • Healthcare systems need to enhance their response to stroke cases.
"Awareness and education are key in fighting against stroke. Prevention can save lives."

In conclusion, increasing public awareness and understanding of stroke risk factors are integral to reducing its prevalence and impact on society.

item.title: Fact Check: Can bamboo layer and coconut oil make vitiligo disappear in a few days? - Medical Dialogues
item.description:
Can Bamboo Layer and Coconut Oil Make Vitiligo Disappear in a Few Days?

Publication Date: [Insert Date]   Source: Medical Dialogues

The article discusses a claim circulating on Instagram that a mixture of bamboo powder and coconut oil can cure vitiligo in just a few days. This claim is identified as false, with evidence showing that while bamboo and coconut oil may have some benefits for skin health, they do not cure vitiligo.

Key Points:

  • The claim that bamboo powder mixed with coconut oil can cure vitiligo is false.
  • Proper diagnosis and treatment are essential for vitiligo management.
  • Dr. Shireen Furtado explains evidence-based treatment options like topical corticosteroids and phototherapy.
  • No scientific evidence supports the use of bamboo powder for treating vitiligo.
  • Vitiligo is a complex condition that requires medical oversight.
Dr. Shireen Furtado: "No, such remedies are not scientifically proven to cure vitiligo. Effective treatments require time and medical guidance."

The conclusion emphasizes the importance of consulting healthcare professionals for effective vitiligo treatments, as unverified remedies can be harmful.

item.title: Health Matters | 'Too Good To Be True': Russia Claims Cancer Vaccine Discovery, Oncologists Sceptical - News18
item.description:
Russia Claims Breakthrough in Cancer Vaccine Development Amidst Skepticism

Date: December 23, 2024

Source: News18

Russia has announced a significant advancement in cancer treatment with a claimed mRNA vaccine intended for cancer patients. This announcement has sparked both excitement and skepticism among global oncologists.

  • Russia asserts development of an mRNA cancer vaccine to be distributed free.
  • Oncologists express skepticism due to lack of credible data supporting the claims.
  • Pre-clinical trials reportedly show effectiveness in tumor suppression.
  • Experts emphasize the complexity of developing effective cancer vaccines.
  • The use of artificial intelligence is proposed to personalize vaccine development.
“Vaccines are available currently for a few cancers which are thought to be due to viral infections. I will wait for the final data to come out before getting very excited.” - Dr. Gaurav Dixit

This claimed breakthrough raises questions on the veracity and feasibility of creating a universal cancer vaccine, requiring further data and validation from clinical trials.

item.title: Heart muscle can regenerate in people with artificial hearts - The Sentinel Assam
item.description:
Heart Muscle Can Regenerate in People with Artificial Hearts

Date: New York

Source: IANS

Recent research indicates that some patients with artificial hearts may be capable of regenerating heart muscle, potentially leading to new treatments for heart failure.

  • A study co-led by the University of Arizona reveals heart muscle regeneration in a subset of artificial heart patients.
  • The research suggests that heart muscle can regenerate at over six times the rate compared to healthy hearts.
  • Current treatments for advanced heart failure primarily involve artificial hearts and medication to slow progression.
  • The findings may change therapeutic approaches and improve outcomes for heart failure patients.
“This is the strongest evidence we have, so far, that human heart muscle cells can actually regenerate, which really is exciting...” - Hesham Sadek

These discoveries could lead to advancements in the treatment of heart failure, as scientists aim to enhance the heart's innate regeneration capacity.

item.title: How to know your heart is healthy? - Health shots
item.description:
How to Know If Your Heart is Healthy?

Published Dec 23, 2024 by Healthshots

A healthy heart is essential for overall well-being, and there are several signs that indicate your heart is in good shape.

  • Heart Rate: A normal heart rate is typically between 60 to 100 beats per minute when at rest.
  • Breathing Pattern: Normal breathing should be relaxed, without excessive shortness of breath.
  • Blood Pressure: Healthy blood pressure levels are about 120/80 mmHg.
  • Energy Levels: Feeling energetic throughout the day is a sign of a healthy heart.
  • Cholesterol Levels: Healthy cholesterol levels reduce the risk of heart disease.
  • Good Oral Health: Healthy oral health reduces the risk of heart diseases.

item.title: 10 Winter Superfoods That Are High In Vitamin D - TheHealthSite
item.description:
10 Winter Superfoods That Are High In Vitamin D

Publication Date: Not specified Source: The Health Site

As winter arrives, some of you may experience an acute drop in your body's natural vitamin D levels. Here is a list of foods that can help you fight Vitamin D deficiency naturally.

Key Points

  • Fatty fish like salmon and mackerel are excellent sources of vitamin D.
  • Cod liver oil offers about 1,360 IU per tablespoon.
  • Fortified dairy products provide a practical way to increase vitamin D intake.
  • Egg yolks contribute around 37 IU of vitamin D each.
  • Certain UV-exposed mushrooms can offer up to 1,000 IU of vitamin D.
  • Fortified cereals can vary from 40 to 100 IU per serving.
  • Beef liver and cheese also add to overall vitamin D intake.
  • Fortified orange juice can provide around 100 IU per cup.
“Make sure to consult with a doctor or an expert if you find yourself dealing with serious symptoms of this essential vitamin deficiency.”

Incorporating these foods into your diet can help maintain healthy vitamin D levels during winter, promoting overall health.

item.title: A predictive model for functional cure in chronic HBV patients treated with pegylated interferon alpha: a comparative study of multiple algorithms based on clinical data - Virology Journal
item.description:
A Predictive Model for Functional Cure in Chronic HBV Patients Treated with Pegylated Interferon Alpha: A Comparative Study of Multiple Algorithms Based on Clinical Data

Published: 23 December 2024 | Source: Virology Journal

This study develops a multivariate predictive model utilizing clinical data to assess the rate of HBsAg clearance in chronic hepatitis B patients undergoing treatment with pegylated interferon alpha. The model aims to enhance treatment personalization and outcomes.

  • The model includes baseline log2(HBsAg), age, gender, neutrophil count at week 12, and HBsAg decline rate at week 12 as predictors.
  • 224 patients were analyzed, with a clearance rate of 25.45% observed by week 48.
  • The logistic regression model outperformed other machine learning algorithms with an AUC of 0.858.
  • Key factors contributing to the model's predictions include baseline HBsAg levels and demographic data.
“The combined use of clinical indicators can serve as a foundational predictive model for anticipating HBsAg clearance.”

The findings underscore the importance of using machine learning algorithms to improve outcomes in chronic hepatitis B management.

item.title: Health insurance in a world of rising air pollution - Deccan Herald
item.description:
Health Insurance in a World of Rising Air Pollution

Published: 23 December 2024, 03:20 IST

Air pollution in India has shifted from a distant concern to a pressing issue impacting daily life and health. The financial burdens linked to pollution-related health issues highlight the critical need for adequate health insurance coverage.

  • Immediate health problems such as asthma and bronchitis can arise from polluted air.
  • Long-term exposure can lead to chronic illnesses like heart disease and cancer.
  • Health insurance becomes essential to manage unexpected medical costs associated with pollution-related health issues.

The financial toll of pollution-related illnesses is significant, often accompanied by hospitalisation costs and loss of income due to missed workdays. Health insurance can cover hospitalization and treatment for pollution-linked ailments, provide critical illness riders, and ensure daily cash benefits. With unemployment and the high cost of care, insurance serves as a safety net for families.

Investing in a comprehensive health insurance policy ensures financial preparedness for immediate and long-term health challenges posed by pollution.

item.title: Talaromyces marneffei central nervous system infection unveiled by the novel Mp1p antigen detection assay in AIDS patient - BMC Infectious Diseases
item.description:
Talaromyces marneffei central nervous system infection unveiled by the novel Mp1p antigen detection assay in AIDS patient

Published: 23 December 2024 | Source: BMC Infectious Diseases

This case report highlights a rare instance of Talaromyces marneffei causing central nervous system infection in an AIDS patient, emphasizing the effective use of Mp1p antigen detection for early diagnosis.

  • Background: Talaromyces marneffei infections are severe in AIDS patients, often disseminated, affecting various systems including the CNS.
  • Case Presentation: A 35-year-old woman presented with dizziness and headaches, and ultimately diagnosed with CNS infection due to T. marneffei, confirmed using Mp1p antigen detection in CSF.
  • Treatment: Patient condition improved significantly after antifungal treatment.
  • Conclusions: CSF Mp1p antigen testing is crucial for diagnosing CNS infections in AIDS patients.
“If the patient has symptoms of central nervous system, the Cerebrospinal fluid Mp1p antigen and culture should be performed to make a definitive diagnosis.”
